I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  recognizes  the  importance  of  information  and 
communications  technology  (ICT)  to  improve  education  and  foster  development  in  the 
Asia-Pacific region. In 2002, the ADB approved a sector policy1 encouraging innovations in ICT 
and learning technologies. This policy recommends adapting such technologies, particularly for 
improving  access  to  and  quality  of  education  in  remote  areas  and  among  disadvantaged 
communities  in  the  developing  member  countries  (DMCs).  The  potential  of  new  learning 
technologies is stimulating DMC governments to incorporate ICT into their education and training 
policies and strategies. The importance of partnerships with the private sector in this field is 
increasingly recognized in the DMCs, and the private sector is keen to provide cost-efficient and 
innovative ICT solutions to improve education and assist educational institutions to use them 
efficiently. With this in mind, ADB and the Asian Development Bank Institute (ADBI) set up a 
series of international conferences (2004–2007)2 to examine with stakeholders e-learning as a 
means to improve access to quality schooling throughout Asia. The proposed regional technical 
assistance (TA) will support this process by implementing policy and strategy studies to support 
development of broader ICT in education frameworks, as well as specific pilot studies on ICT and 
e-learning innovations to provide in-depth understanding of the potential and feasibility of such 
innovations. The studies will inform international conferences that will be held in 2006 and 2007. 
The TA will partially finance the cost of these conferences. The TA concept paper was endorsed 
by the Poverty Reduction Cooperation Fund  peer review in January 2005.3 Governments of 
Bangladesh, Mongolia, Nepal and Samoa have approved implementation of the pilot studies in 
their countries under the TA. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  The approach to ICT in education and training has been based predominantly on the 
supply and use of PCs and software, and, where feasible, linked with Internet access. This has 
not proven to be the most cost-efficient approach in several DMCs due to (i) high costs arising 
from  the  start-up  arrangements  (including  upgrading  physical  infrastructure),  (ii)  often 
inappropriate selection of hardware and software and safeguards for installation and regular 
maintenance of equipment, and (iii) extensive and often incorrectly focused in-service training of 
teachers undertaken in implementing the approach in schools and training institutions. DMCs’ 
reliance on this approach alone in the past may have actually increased inequity in access to 
knowledge,  education,  and  training.  This  may  be  particularly  true  in  DMCs  where  such  a 
high-cost approach has proven not feasible to implement in all areas and for all groups of the 
society. To effectively reduce the digital divide within DMCs, appropriate ICT policy and strategic 
frameworks are needed to maximize access and flow of knowledge to a wider range of users, 
particularly by utilizing the potential and opportunities arising from the latest developments in ICT. 
In recent years, increased computing power combined with improved wireless and user-friendly 
satellite technology and reduced telecommunication costs have contributed to reducing space 
and time barriers for information access and exchange. These opportunities for utilizing more 
cost-efficient and user-friendly ICT solutions in education and training, and to reach all groups of 
society—including  the  poor,  users  in  remote  areas,  and  other  disadvantaged  groups—have 
become increasingly feasible also in poorer DMCs.  
 
                                                 
1  ADB. 2002. Our Framework Policies and Strategies: Education. Manila

3.  ADB, in line with its education policy, is responding to the increasing demand in the DMCs 
for assistance with ICT in education. To be successful, however, this effort will require support 
from concurrent investments into appropriate science and technology, as well as centers of 
excellence, pursuing ICT innovations in education. These major thrusts are closely intertwined. 
When carefully synergized in individual DMCs, they together will provide a strong impetus for 
increasing access to and improving quality of education through innovative teaching and learning 
technologies.  If  these  will  be  appropriate  for  decentralized  education  delivery  to  such 
disadvantaged communities as those in poor and remote areas, then they can greatly contribute 
to reducing poverty in the DMCs.  
 
4.  It is well understood that e-learning will shape the way teachers teach and students learn 
in the future. Examples include provision of e-textbooks to remote areas via the computer or 
satellite linked to handheld devices on demand connections, and e-teacher in-service training 
using innovative technologies that facilitate implementing decentralized teacher training strategies 
and information sharing directly to teachers in remote schools. ADB recently undertook a major 
initial study to map out the situation in the region.4 In addition, some development partners have 
prepared useful basic data and analysis.5 However, as the situation in this field is evolving rapidly, 
there is a need to provide data updates and undertake comprehensive studies to support policy 
and strategy development. These should include in-depth analysis of the demand for various ICT 
solutions in education, and, in particular the intertwined educational development areas of ICT, 
science and technology, and centers of excellence. Also needed is a comprehensive comparative 
analysis of these intertwined areas in the region’s middle- and low-income countries.  
 
5.  ADB’s possible role in financing such a holistic development approach will be important to 
explore, as development in DMCs will depend increasingly on their abilities to produce, process, 
understand, use, and commercialize scientific and technological knowledge in ways appropriate 
to each DMC’s culture and aspirations. While some middle-income countries have managed to 
create pockets of science and technology capacity that at least partially serve their economic and 
social ambitions, the vast majority of the DMCs have severe capacity deficits in this area. A lack 
of capacity among many DMCs to even access and utilize advances in science and technology 
has  prevented  them  from  capturing  the  benefits  that  have  become  commonplace  in  the 
developed world. Often it is the poor people in DMCs who suffer most from the lack of adequate 
services and products. The barriers to seizing the opportunities for using science and technology 
need to be addressed. Timely and appropriate local adoption of science and technology often 
requires significant investment into building indigenous technological capacity.  
 
6.  On the one hand, improving science and technology capacity in general is important for 
development.  Such  efforts  can  be  supported,  for  example,  through  increased  emphasis  on 
science- and technology-related subjects at appropriate levels of formal education, and through 
increased investment in research. On the other hand, it will be important to invest in science and 
technology  that  will  be  useful  for  developing  appropriate  ICT  for  accessing  knowledge  and 
supporting e-learning for continuous human resources development. That is necessary if the 
DMCs are to progress toward the knowledge-based economy, improved economic growth, and 
reduced  poverty.  DMCs  need  assistance  in  preparing  appropriate  policy  and  regulatory 
frameworks to facilitate a conducive environment for ICT. In particular, they need help to develop 
appropriate ICT and e-learning applications to improve formal education in schools, colleges, and 
universities,  as  well  as  for  continuous  lifelong  adult  education  and  training  in  line  with  the 
development needs in various sectors of the society.

7.  In addition to the broader policy and strategy studies, it will be necessary to undertake 
studies of innovative ongoing pilot projects in ICT in education. In particular, these should aim to 
disseminate educational knowledge to remote areas where the poor disproportionately reside and 
to other disadvantaged groups, and to facilitate in-depth understanding of the contribution these 
developments can make in reducing the digital divide and poverty. ADB already has ICT projects 
in the education sectors in Mongolia and Samoa. Here, schoolnet6 operations include production 
of learning materials for computers used in poor communities. The schoolnet project in Samoa7 
provides computers in schools—including Internet availability—to increase access to learning 
materials and new technologies for teaching and learning. The project allows greater access to 
supplementary reading references and reading materials via computer. In Mongolia, ADB is 
supporting  ICT  for  the  Innovating  Rural  Education  in  Mongolia  Project 8 and  the  Second 
Education Development Project.9 These projects have gained experience in applying ICT to 
improve teaching and learning materials. E-textbook pilot innovations can be studied in these 
ongoing projects in Samoa and Mongolia.  
 
8.  Likewise, ADB has projects to improve teacher training in Bangladesh10 and Nepal.11 In 
Nepal, the ADB-funded loan project supports the Government’s teacher education activities, 
which provide in-service training and materials to primary school teachers. It will be important to 
explore how these materials and in-service training can be improved by providing appropriate 
e-learning  access  to  schools.  The  potential  impact  of  e-learning  in  remote  disadvantaged 
communities can be piloted in a sample of schools from the ongoing project. A large-scale reform 
for teacher education has recently commenced in Bangladesh with the support of an ADB-funded 
loan project. The project includes provision for teacher education through distance education 
methods and funding for developing innovative approaches to teacher training institutions and 
schools. It is important to undertake pilot studies to assess the potential that e-teacher training 
innovations may have in a large-scale teacher education reform. 
 
9.  The ADB/ADBI international conference in 2004 set the stage for conference agendas for 
the following years (footnote 2). Each conference is to focus on e-learning topics and to facilitate 
exchange  of  information  among  DMCs,  experts,  the  private  sector,  and  other  stakeholders. 
Moreover,  the  conference  will  bring  these  people  together  to  propose  concept  papers  for 
incorporating into the country strategy and program (CSP) process. Participants include also 
poverty experts to offer insights on how innovative e-learning solutions can overcome the digital 
divide between communities and contribute to reduction of poverty. Outcomes from the pilot 
studies implemented under the TA will be reported back during the conferences in 2006 and 2007, 
which will focus on e-textbooks and e-teacher training, respectively.

III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
10.  The impact of the TA will be appropriate and increased utilization of innovative ICT in 
education in DMCs. The outcome will be a consensus reached on the appropriate innovative ICT 
in education solutions and their applicability, replicability, and sustainability in a larger scale in 
DMC country contexts.   
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
11.  The TA will have three components. The first component will include implementing studies 
to support policy and strategy development in the area of ICT in education. It will analyze and 
assess in-depth the demand in DMCs for innovative ICT in education. The focus will be on the 
contribution the innovations can make to reducing poverty by improving the quality of education 
and access to it. Also addressed will be the feasibility and sustainability of such innovations on a 
larger scale, and the financing needs as well as cost-sharing possibilities (including the role for 
the private sector) in the DMCs. Special attention will be given to the roles of science and 
technology and centers of excellence in supporting development of feasible and sustainable ICT 
innovations in education. Possibilities will be explored to extend the potential of ICT applications 
beyond the conventional ICT approach to complementary or alternative innovative solutions, 
where necessary and feasible. The goal will be to strengthen decentralized education delivery in 
order to narrow the digital divide and reach the poorest and other disadvantaged groups. Demand, 
feasibility and sustainability factors will be compared between middle- and low-income DMCs. 
Outputs will include reports, technical and discussion papers, CD-ROMs, DVDs, PowerPoint 
e-files, and other knowledge products, as appropriate, for use by the ADB and DMCs. The 
analysis and outputs will be important also for the conferences (the third component of the TA). 
 
12.  The second component will include implementation of specific pilot studies in Bangladesh, 
Mongolia, Nepal, and Samoa. The studies will piggyback ongoing ADB-funded projects. Key 
activities will include linking pilot studies to ongoing projects to support trial interventions in 
e-textbook development and e-teacher training in a small sample of schools under each ongoing 
project. Some additional software and equipment may be required to supplement or complement 
the existing ICT arrangements in the schools participating in the pilot studies. Depending upon 
the circumstances in each country, consultants will identify, acquire, and install the additional ICT 
equipment and software for teaching and materials, or they will adopt other appropriate ICT and 
e-learning arrangements. In consultation with the management and staff of ongoing projects and 
other stakeholders in the four DMCs, the consultants will design the pilot study interventions, 
provide  necessary  orientation  for  teachers  and  students,  implement  the  interventions,  and 
evaluate  those  using  focused  interviews.  In  addition  to  the  use  of  e-textbooks,  additional 
off-the-shelf  software  learning  materials  (supplementary  materials,  educational  games, 
references etc.) will be used, as appropriate, in those schools participating in the pilot studies. 
This will be supported with training and followed by in-depth focused interviews and comparisons 
across schools. The pilots for e-teacher training will design, implement, and evaluate new ways of 
helping teachers put learning into practice. The recommendations will stress micro-level solutions 
in classrooms. Outputs will include reports, technical and discussion papers, CD-ROMs, DVDs, 
PowerPoint e-files, and other knowledge products, as appropriate. The pilot studies will follow the 
schedule of the international conferences. Pilot studies on e-textbooks will be carried out in 2006 
and findings reported to the international conference on e-textbooks to be held in the 4th quarter 
of 2006. Pilot studies on e-teacher training will be completed in 2007 and findings reported to the 
international conference on e-teacher training to be held in the 4th quarter of 2007. Special 
attention will be paid to possibilities for replicating innovative ICT and e-learning on a larger scale, 
as well as to gauging the practical sustainability and actual financial costs. The recommendations

5
will be used by ADB and ADBI to mobilize Asian e-learning networks that feed into ongoing and 
future ADB operations in education that employ ICT. 
 
13.  The third component will support the ongoing series of international conferences on ICT in 
education sponsored by ADB and ADBI. These funds will allow more DMC members to travel to 
the conferences in order to learn and share ideas about e-learning innovations. The TA funds 
also  will  fund  participation  by  experts  in  education  technology  and  poverty  reduction.  The 
conferences will support greater coordination and network building on ICT in education between 
ADB,  ADBI,  DMCs,  the  private  sector,  and  other  stakeholders.  They  will  help  to  spread 
knowledge and information within the network on the latest technological innovations and their 
potential for reducing poverty by improving the quality of education and access to it. The TA will 
provide partial support to finance the conferences. Outputs will include, for example, conference 
proceedings, DMC concept papers for e-learning projects for potential incorporation into CSPs, 
plans for further studies, and private-public partnership funding programs identified to support 
e-learning. A web page at the ADB education website will be developed to encourage and 
facilitate continuous dialogue and debate on ICT and e-learning issues.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
14.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $1,000,000. ADB will finance $800,000 equivalent. 
The  TA  will  be  financed  on  a  grant  basis  by  the  Poverty  Reduction  Cooperation  Fund, 
administered by ADB. ADBI will provide parallel financing of $200,000 equivalent. Appendix 2 
includes details of cost estimates and the financing plan. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
15.  The  TA  will  be  implemented  over  24  months,  commencing  in  January  2006  with 
completion expected in December 2007. ADB will be the Executing Agency for the TA. The 
Capacity Development and Governance Division of the Regional and Sustainable Development 
Department  will  be  responsible  for  administration  of  the  TA.  An  advisory  group  will  guide 
implementation of the TA. It will comprise representatives of ADB, ADBI, DMCs, experts, and the 
private sector participating in the international conferences organized by ADB and ADBI. The 
advisory group will have meetings during the conferences and communicate also through video 
conferences and e-mails, as and when necessary, during the TA implementation period.  
 
16.  The TA will utilize 53 person-months of consultancy inputs, to be provided by three 
international consultants (13 person-months) and eight domestic consultants (40 person-months). 
Consultants will be engaged through a firm in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of 
Consultants and other arrangements satisfactory to ADB for engaging domestic consultants. The 
quality  and  cost-based  method  will  be  used  for  selecting  consultants.  The  team  leader  will 
prepare  (i)  an  inception  report,  including  a  detailed  work  plan,  within  1  month  from  TA 
commencement; (ii) a mid-term progress report by the end of 2006; and (iii) a final report by the 
end of 2007. Procurement will follow ADB’s Guidelines for Procurement. Upon completion of the 
TA, the participating schools will retain the equipment for use in follow-up programs.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
17.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $800,000 to be financed on a 
grant  basis  by  the  Poverty  Reduction  Cooperation  Fund  for  the  Innovative  Information  and 
Communications Technology in Education, and Its Potential for Reducing Poverty in the Asia and 
Pacific Region, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Policy  and  Planning  Expert/Team  Leader  (one  international  consultant, 
5 person-months) 
 
1.  The consultant will have expertise in education policy and planning, including substantial 
experience in issues of information and communications technology (ICT) in education. The 
consultant will undertake studies to support policy and strategy development in this area in 
developing member countries (DMCs). For this purpose, the consultant will do the following: 
(i)  Analyze and assess the demand for innovative ICT in education in the Asia and 
Pacific region, as well as the contribution the innovations can make to reducing 
poverty by improving the quality of education and access to it.  
(ii)  Analyze and assess feasibility and sustainability of such innovations in a larger 
scale, and financing needs as well as cost-sharing possibilities (including the role 
of the private sector) in the DMCs.  
(iii)  Explore  possibilities  to  widen  the  potential  of  ICT  applications  beyond  the 
conventional ICT approach to complementary or alternative innovative solutions, 
where necessary and feasible, as well as to strengthen decentralized education 
delivery  to  help  narrow  the  digital  divide  and  reach  the  poorest  and  other 
disadvantaged groups. 
(iv)  Analyze  and  assess  the  roles  of  science  and  technology  and  centers  of 
excellence  in  supporting  the  development  of  feasible  and  sustainable  ICT 
innovations in education, along with options for strengthening in this field the 
roles of science and technology and centers of excellence in the DMCs. 
(v)  Undertake  comparison  of  the  above  (i-iv)  between  middle-income  and 
low-income DMCs.  
 
2.  The  consultant  will  use  data  and  information  available  on  the  Internet  and,  as 
appropriate,  other  sources  of  information.1 In  addition,  the  consultant  will  visit  DMCs  and 
regional specialized institutions and organizations, as appropriate. The consultant will take into 
account past2 and current3 activities of Asian Development Bank (ADB) and other development 
partners in ICT in education as well as private sector initiatives. 
 
3.   As part of TA inception activities, the consultant will prepare a detailed work plan for 
carrying out the policy and strategy studies. The consultant will prepare reports, technical and 
discussion papers, CD-ROMs, DVDs, PowerPoint e-files, and other knowledge products, as 
appropriate, for use of the ADB and DMCs. The consultant will assist in preparing international 
conferences, which will be organized by ADB and Asian Development Bank Institute (ADBI) with 
DMCs and other stakeholders in 2006 and 2007. As required, the consultant will present results

4.   The  consultant  will  provide  leadership  for  the  consultant  team  (international  and 
domestic), as well as to coordinate the work planning of the team and the delivery of inputs and 
outputs of team members. The consultant will prepare a TA inception report, mid-term progress 
report, and final report. 
 
B.  Education  Technology  Expert  in  E-Textbooks  (one  international  consultant, 
4 person-months) 
 
5.  The consultant will have expertise in educational technology and experience in applying 
e-textbooks and learning materials. The consultant will work in Mongolia and Samoa to design 
pilot studies on the use of e-textbooks. The consultant will work closely with the domestic 
consultants, and consult the management and staff of the associated ongoing ADB projects, as 
well as other stakeholders, on the study methodology, schedule, selection of schools, and other 
study  arrangements.  The  consultant  will  refine  the  tasks  of  the  domestic  consultants  to 
effectively support and monitor implementation of the pilot studies, training of teachers and 
students of the pilot study schools, and evaluation of results of the pilot studies. 
 
6.  As appropriate and depending on the circumstances in each country, the consultant will 
identify, acquire, and install in the pilot study schools additional ICT equipment and software for 
the purpose of the study or adopt other ICT and e-learning arrangements for the study. In 
addition  to  e-textbooks,  additional  off-the-shelf  software  learning  materials  (supplementary 
materials, educational games, references, etc.) will be used, as appropriate, in the pilot study 
schools.  
 
7.  In both pilot study countries, Mongolia and Samoa, the consultant will specifically do the 
following: 
(i)  Determine and finalize the experimental design of the pilot studies, timeline, and 
costing (materials, training, implementation, and evaluation). 
(ii)  Set up the pilot studies and identify and approve equipment/materials to be 
procured. 
(iii)  Design  the  training  program  and  schedule  to  be  implemented  by  domestic 
consultants. 
(iv)  Prepare the interview schedule for monitoring and evaluation to be used for 
interviews by domestic consultants, including indicators covering access, quality, 
cost, technical capacity, and financing.4 
(v)  Refine the terms of reference and work plan for domestic consultants, as well as 
train them to implement the pilot study and evaluation.  
 
8.  The consultant will prepare reports, technical and discussion papers, CD-ROMs, DVDs, 
PowerPoint e-files, and other knowledge products on e-textbook pilot studies, as appropriate. 
The consultant will assist with preparing material for the international conference on e-textbooks 
                                                 
4  The consultant will include dimensions covering the following (minimum): (i) practical factors (such as funding 
required,  infrastructure,  classroom  layout,  staff  development,  student  and  teacher  support  services), 
(ii) pedagogical issues (catering to individual needs, multimedia assessment, impacts on teachers, access to 
worldwide activities and resources for teachers and students), and (iii) policy issues (connecting people, ICT 
literacy, instructional policies). As appropriate, the consultant may develop additional dimensions, and/or adopt 
additional dimensions as specified in existing guidelines, for example, in the ICT in Education Toolkit, which is 
being prepared by UNESCO.

that will be organized by ADB and ADBI with the DMCs and other stakeholders in 2006. The 
consultant will present the findings of the pilot studies at the conference. 
 
C.  Education Technology Expert in E-Teacher Training (one international consultant, 
4 person-months) 
 
9.  The consultant will have expertise in education technology and experience in e-teacher 
training and will work in Bangladesh and Nepal to design pilot studies on e-teacher training. 
Working closely with the domestic consultants, the consultant will advise management and staff 
of  the  associated  ongoing  ADB  projects,  as  well  as  other  stakeholders,  on  the  study 
methodology, schedule, selection of schools, and other study arrangements. The consultant will 
refine the tasks of the domestic consultants to effectively support and monitor implementation of 
the pilots, training of teachers and students of the pilot study schools, and evaluation of results 
of the pilots.  
 
10.  As appropriate and depending on the circumstances in each country, the consultant will 
identify, acquire, and install in the pilot study schools additional ICT equipment and software for 
the purpose of the study or adopt other ICT and e-learning arrangements for the study.  
 
11.  In both pilot study countries, Bangladesh and Nepal, the consultant will specifically do 
the following: 
(i)  Determine and finalize the experimental design of the pilot studies, timeline, and 
costing (materials, training, implementation, and evaluation). 
(ii)  Set up the pilot studies and identify and approve equipment/materials to be 
procured. 
(iii)  Design  the  training  program  and  schedule  to  be  implemented  by  domestic 
consultants. 
(iv)  Prepare the interview schedule for monitoring and evaluation to be used for 
interviews by domestic consultants, including indicators covering access, quality, 
cost, technical capacity, and financing (footnote 4).5  
(v)  Refine the terms of reference and work plan for domestic consultants, as well as 
train them to implement the pilot study and evaluation.  
 
12.  The consultant will prepare reports, technical and discussion papers, CD-ROMs, DVDs, 
PowerPoint  e-files,  and  other  knowledge  products  on  e-teacher  training  pilot  studies,  as 
appropriate. The consultant will assist with preparing material for the international conference on 
e-teacher training that will be organized by ADB and ADBI with DMCs and other stakeholders in 
2007. The consultant will present the findings of the pilot studies at the conference. 
 
D.  Curriculum and Learning Materials Specialists (two domestic consultants, one in 
Mongolia and one in Samoa, 7 person-months each) 
 
13.  The consultant will have experience in curriculum and learning material development in 
primary and/or secondary education, along with experience in providing training in the use of 
materials. The consultant will assist the international consultant in designing a pilot study on the 
use of e-textbooks. The consultant will become familiar with the e-textbooks/materials and the 
expectations for their use in the pilot study schools. For the purpose of the pilot study, the

consultant will design and implement a training program for teachers and students of the pilot 
study schools. The consultant will specifically do the following: 
(i)  Assist with the design of the pilot study on e-textbooks. 
(ii)  Assist with setting up practical arrangements and logistics for the pilot study. 
(iii)  Design and implement training of teachers and students of the pilot study schools. 
(iv)  Coordinate and guide the implementation of the pilot study. 
(v)  Coordinate  closely  with  the  domestic  evaluation  specialist  and  assist  in 
organizing arrangements for the evaluation. 
(vi)  Consult  closely  with  management  and  staff  of  the  associated  ongoing  ADB 
projects, and other stakeholders, on the study implementation.  
(vii)  Assist the international consultant, as appropriate, in preparing reports, technical 
and  discussion  papers,  CD-ROMs,  DVDs,  PowerPoint  e-files,  and  other 
knowledge products on the e-textbook pilot study. 
 
E.  Teacher Training Specialists (two domestic consultants, one in Bangladesh and one in 
Nepal, 7 person-months each) 
 
14.  The consultant will have experience as a teacher trainer in primary and/or secondary 
education, and in development of materials for teacher training programs The consultant will 
assist  the  international  consultant  in  designing  a  pilot  study  on  e-teacher  training.  The 
consultant will become familiar with the e-teacher training methodologies and materials and the 
expectations on their application in the pilot study schools. For the purpose of the pilot study, 
the consultant will design and implement a training program for teachers and students of the 
pilot study schools. The consultant will specifically do the following: 
(i)  Assist with the design of the pilot study on e-teacher training. 
(ii)  Assist with setting up practical arrangements and logistics for the pilot study. 
(iii)  Design and implement training of teachers and students of the pilot study schools. 
(iv)  Coordinate and guide the implementation of the pilot study. 
(v)  Coordinate closely with the domestic evaluation specialist in designing evaluation 
of the study and assist in organizing arrangements for the evaluation. 
(vi)  Consult  closely  with  management  and  staff  of  the  associated  ongoing  ADB 
projects, and other stakeholders, on the study implementation.  
(vii)  Assist the international consultant, as appropriate, in preparing reports, technical 
and  discussion  papers,  CD-ROMs,  DVDs,  PowerPoint  e-files,  and  other 
knowledge products on the e-teacher training pilot study. 
 
F.  Evaluation Specialists, E-Textbooks (two domestic consultants, one in Mongolia and 
one in Samoa, 3 person-months each) 
 
15.  The  consultant  will  have  experience  in  developing  and  evaluating  curriculum  and 
learning materials in primary and/or secondary education. The consultant will have experience 
in  both  quantitative  and  qualitative  evaluation  in  education,  and  in  practical  application  of 
evaluation techniques, data collection, analysis, and reporting. The consultant will work closely 
with the international consultant, the domestic curriculum and learning materials specialist, the 
management and staff of the associated ongoing ADB funded project, and other stakeholders. 
The consultant will plan and carry out an evaluation process appropriate for the pilot study. The 
consultant will familiarize him/herself with the e-textbooks and materials adopted for use in the 
pilot schools. In addition to including teachers and students among the target groups of the 
evaluation,  the  consultant  will  obtain  data  and  feedback,  as  appropriate,  also  from  head 
teachers, members of the community (PTA, parents, etc.) of the pilot study schools, and from 
other stakeholders. The consultant will specifically do the following:

Appendix 3  13 
(i)  Design in detail the evaluation of the use of e-textbooks in the pilot schools, 
including  evaluation  methodology,  data  collection  techniques,  analysis,  and 
reporting. 
(ii)  Organize practical arrangements and logistics for the evaluation process. 
(iii)  Where necessary, provide orientation for target groups of the evaluation. 
(iv)  Consult  closely  with  management  and  staff  of  the  associated  ongoing  ADB 
projects and other stakeholders on the evaluation’s implementation.  
(v)  Assist the international consultant, as appropriate, in preparing reports, technical 
and  discussion  papers,  CD-ROMs,  DVDs,  PowerPoint  e-files,  and  other 
knowledge products on the e-textbook pilot study. 
 
G.  Evaluation  Specialist,  E-Teacher  Training  (two  domestic  consultants,  one  in 
Bangladesh and one in Nepal, 3 person-months each) 
 
16.  The consultant will have experience in teacher training and evaluation of teacher training 
programs/training events and associated materials in primary and/or secondary education. The 
consultant has experience in both quantitative and qualitative evaluation in education, as well as 
in practical application of evaluation techniques, data collection, analysis, and reporting. The 
consultant will work closely with the international consultant, the domestic teacher training 
specialist, the management and staff of the associated ongoing ADB-funded project, and other 
stakeholders. The consultant will plan and carry out an evaluation process appropriate for the 
pilot study. The consultant will familiarize him/herself with the e-teacher training methods and 
materials adopted for use in the pilot schools. In addition to including teachers and students 
among the target groups of the evaluation, the consultant will obtain data and feedback, as 
appropriate, also from head teachers, members of the community (PTA, parents, etc) of the pilot 
study schools, and from other stakeholders. The consultant will specifically do the following: 
(i)  Design in detail the evaluation of the e-teacher training methods and materials 
used  in  the  pilot  schools,  including  evaluation  methodology,  data  collection 
techniques, analysis, and reporting. 
(ii)  Organize practical arrangements and logistics for the evaluation process. 
(iii)  Where necessary, provide orientation for target groups of the evaluation.  
(iv)  Consult  closely  with  management  and  staff  of  the  associated  ongoing  ADB 
projects and other stakeholders on the evaluation’s implementation.  
(v)  Assist the international consultant, as appropriate, in preparing reports, technical 
and  discussion  papers,  CD-ROMs,  DVDs,  PowerPoint  e-files,  and  other 
knowledge products, on the e-teacher training pilot study.
